awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Stochastic processes and embeddings on networks
awd_abstract_narration:
Random processes on networks play a major role in a wide range of areas including mathematical physics, machine learning, and theoretical computer science. One such question we will address involves analysing algorithms for detecting sub-communities within a social network by investigating the graph of friendship relations. The proposal addresses questions from combinatorics and computer science about when random combinatorial and computational problems have solutions, such as when there is a colouring in a random graph.  Ideas from statistical physics give predictions for these thresholds which we will mathematically prove.  It also studies questions of how long it takes random processes on networks, such as the Glauber dynamics Markov chain, to reach their equilibrium distribution and how this depends on their initial starting position.  Such processes are used as algorithms for sampling high dimensional distributions.  The proposal focuses on development of mathematical theory with a view to better understanding these problems.  Finally the proposal will support the development of new graduate courses in discrete probability and stochastic process on random graphs as well as providing research opportunities for graduate and undergraduate researchers.

The main theme of this proposal is the development of new theory and applications across a range of stochastic processes on networks. One aspect involves studying phase transitions of Gibbs measures on random graphs, particularly random constraint satisfaction problems.  Here we hope to establish conjectures from statistical physics for a range of models such as the chromatic and independence numbers on random graphs.  A second theme is the development of new tools for establishing rough isometries and other geometric notions of closeness between random metric spaces.  In particular we will consider whether independent copies of Poisson processes, percolation clusters and SLE curves are rough isometries or quasi-symmetries.  Finally the proposal will consider Markov random fields such as the Ising model on lattices.  At high temperatures it will consider the question of universality of the cutoff phenomena as well as the effect of different initial conditions on the mixing time.  At low temperatures it will pursue a better understanding of Ising interfaces in order to establish rapid mixing results.

Intellectual Merit

Random Constraint Satisfaction Problems

At the intersection of probability theory and theoretical computer science is the understanding of the space of solutions of Random Constraint Satisfaction Problems such as random K-SAT and random colourings of random graphs. In these models a collection of variables is required to satisfy a series of constraints, chosen at random from some distributions. A series of striking predictions from statistical physics beginning with ideas from Mezard and Parisi and later extended by Krz̧akała, Montanari, Ricci-Tersenghi, Semerjian, and Zdeborová have given precise estimates of the satisfiability thresholds in these models. They, moreover, predict several more transitions describing how the space of solutions shatters into exponentially many clusters. Quantitative predictions are given for the location of each phase transition as well as for the size and number of clusters inside each phase.

In the condensation phase, just before the satisfiability threshold, most of the solutions are predicted to be contained in just a constant number of clusters. With Nam and Sohn we established this behavior for the first time in a sparse constraint satisfaction problem in the regular NAESAT model. This is the first time this has been established in a sparse random CSP and means that close to the satisfiability threshold the distance between two random solutions is concentrated on two points. The proof relies on a fine understanding of the clustering of the solutions and the paper is 175 pages.

First and Last Passage Percolation are models where each location in the plane has a transportation cost and one is interested in the length of the minimal path between two vertices (maximal oriented path in the case of last passage percolation). Last passage percolation with exponential weights is an exactly solvable model in which many quantities can be computed exactly. However, many questions are not amenable to exact computations so I have worked on using a synthesis of integrable results together with more geometric arguments, for example to study the coalescence of geodesic paths. Recently with Basu and Hoffman we established that there are no infinite bi-geodesics.   With Martin and Zhang we determined the distribution along the geodesic which is a mixture of Gamma distributions.

Interacting Particle Systems. We have studyied several different models that represent the transmission of infection or information over networks. The contact process is a model where infected vertices on a network infect their neighbours at one rate and heal at another. The contact process has long been well understood on lattice models. With my student Danny Nam, former postoc Oanh Ngyuen and collaborator Shankar Bhameidi we investigated the contact process on random graphs. Answering an open problem of Durrett, we showed that for low infection rates, the process dies out almost surely on branching process trees with exponential degree distributions but survives with positive probability when the degree distribution has tails heavier than exponential.

With Dauvernge we studied a different model of infections, the SIR model, on a collection of moving particles in the plane.  Kesten and Sidoravicius were able to study the model without recoveries where the location of the particles is in equilibrium.  We developed a flexible new method for analyzing such processes to show that at low recovery rates, infections can continue indefinitely.

 

Broader Impacts

Over the course of this grant 6 PhD students, 3 postdocs and 6 senior thesis students have been trained, working on topics related to the grant.  The PI developed a series of graduate special topics courses on modern discrete probability, Stochastic Processes on graphs and Multiscale methods in probability at Princeton University.
